content: A new proposal has been announced: Create a macos notification group #470. It will be announced at the next meeting to try and draw attention to it, but usually MCPs are not discussed during triage meetings. If you think this would benefit from discussion amongst the team, consider proposing a design meeting.
@T-compiler: Proposal #470 has been seconded, and will be approved in 10 days if no objections are raised.
Who will be members of this group?

I hope that some of the developers, who recently created, reviewed or commented on Macos-related PRs/issues, are willing to join. I will make a list and ping them from the team PR, if the proposal is accepted. I am interested in helping with anything Rust on Macos, so I will join too.
According to the Rustforge documentation a blog post should be written, so I am hoping that we can reach even more volunteers that way.
Hmm, I feel like it makes more sense to ask people ahead of time - if you only end up with 1 or 2 I'm not sure how much value this adds
(maybe the MCP could be accepted conditional on finding a set number of people?)

We can ask during the compiler team meeting how many people there 1. have access to a Mac and, secondarily, 2. use a Mac as their primary Rust development platform. (I for example would say yes to 1. and no to 2.)
I suppose I might also tweet about it. We should be able to gather enough interest to make this happen.

Tweeted this: https://twitter.com/pnkfelix/status/1457799152759283712 which is a poll, not a call for action nor call for volunteers (that comes later in tweet thread). Anyway lets see what comes of it.

Are you a #rustlang contributor who:

- Felix S K II (@pnkfelix)
I would love to help with that. I mainly develop on macOS with an Intel CPU. My new M1-based MacBook Pro is on the way, so I may report any findings on that as well.

I dev mostly on mac, write a lot of darwin-specific code, and even regularly dig through apple's published open source components. I'm not really a rustc contributor (aside from occasional stdlib patches), but I'd almost certainly keep an eye on whatever label ends up getting used for this.
(the M1 is really a game-changer for laptop Rust dev. x.py build went from 12-16 minutes on my 2019 i7 down to 4 minutes on my M1)
/me is thinking about getting an m1 now
M1 is pretty great in single-thread perf. (And this shows there are still a lot to parallelize in compilation)
